speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: SCENE III. Wilds in Gloucestershire.

speaker: BAGOT
text_entry: Enter HENRY BOLINGBROKE and NORTHUMBERLAND, with Forces

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Believe me, noble lord,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: I am a stranger here in Gloucestershire:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: These high wild hills and rough uneven ways

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And yet your fair discourse hath been as sugar,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Making the hard way sweet and delectable.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But I bethink me what a weary way

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In Ross and Willoughby, wanting your company,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which, I protest, hath very much beguiled

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The tediousness and process of my travel:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But theirs is sweetened with the hope to have

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The present benefit which I possess;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And hope to joy is little less in joy

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Than hope enjoy'd: by this the weary lords

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Shall make their way seem short, as mine hath done

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: By sight of what I have, your noble company.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Of much less value is my company

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Than your good words. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter HENRY PERCY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: It is my son, young Harry Percy,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sent from my brother Worcester, whencesoever.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Harry, how fares your uncle?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: I had thought, my lord, to have learn'd his health of you.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Why, is he not with the queen?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Broken his staff of office and dispersed

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: The household of the king.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: What was his reason?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: He was not so resolved when last we spake together.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Because your lordship was proclaimed traitor.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To offer service to the Duke of Hereford,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: What power the Duke of York had levied there;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: No, my good lord, for that is not forgot

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: I never in my life did look on him.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: My gracious lord, I tender you my service,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Such as it is, being tender, raw and young:

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Which elder days shall ripen and confirm

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: To more approved service and desert.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I thank thee, gentle Percy; and be sure

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I count myself in nothing else so happy

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As in a soul remembering my good friends;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, as my fortune ripens with thy love,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It shall be still thy true love's recompense:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My heart this covenant makes, my hand thus seals it.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: How far is it to Berkeley? and what stir

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Keeps good old York there with his men of war?

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: There stands the castle, by yon tuft of trees,

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Mann'd with three hundred men, as I have heard;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: And in it are the Lords of York, Berkeley, and Seymour;

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: None else of name and noble estimate.

speaker: HENRY PERCY
text_entry: Enter LORD ROSS and LORD WILLOUGHBY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A banish'd traitor: all my treasury

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Shall be your love and labour's recompense.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: And far surmounts our labour to attain it.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which, till my infant fortune comes to years,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Stands for my bounty. But who comes here?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter LORD BERKELEY

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: It is my Lord of Berkeley, as I guess.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: My Lord of Hereford, my message is to you.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My lord, my answer is--to Lancaster;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I am come to seek that name in England;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I must find that title in your tongue,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Before I make reply to aught you say.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: Mistake me not, my lord; 'tis not my meaning

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To raze one title of your honour out:

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To you, my lord, I come, what lord you will,

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: From the most gracious regent of this land,

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: The Duke of York, to know what pricks you on

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: To take advantage of the absent time

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: And fright our native peace with self-born arms.

speaker: LORD BERKELEY
text_entry: Enter DUKE OF YORK attended

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I shall not need transport my words by you;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Here comes his grace in person. My noble uncle!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Kneels

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Show me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whose duty is deceiveable and false.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious uncle--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Tut, tut!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Grace me no grace, nor uncle me no uncle:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I am no traitor's uncle; and that word 'grace.'

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In an ungracious mouth is but profane.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Why have those banish'd and forbidden legs

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But then more 'why?' why have they dared to march

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So many miles upon her peaceful bosom,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Frighting her pale-faced villages with war

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And ostentation of despised arms?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Comest thou because the anointed king is hence?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Why, foolish boy, the king is left behind,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And in my loyal bosom lies his power.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Were I but now the lord of such hot youth

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As when brave Gaunt, thy father, and myself

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Rescued the Black Prince, that young Mars of men,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: From forth the ranks of many thousand French,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O, then how quickly should this arm of mine.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now prisoner to the palsy, chastise thee

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And minister correction to thy fault!

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: On what condition stands it and wherein?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Even in condition of the worst degree,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In gross rebellion and detested treason:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Before the expiration of thy time,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In braving arms against thy sovereign.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But as I come, I come for Lancaster.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You are my father, for methinks in you

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: A wandering vagabond; my rights and royalties

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Pluck'd from my arms perforce and given away

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: If that my cousin king be King of England,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: It must be granted I am Duke of Lancaster.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: You have a son, Aumerle, my noble cousin;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Had you first died, and he been thus trod down,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: He should have found his uncle Gaunt a father,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: I am denied to sue my livery here,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And yet my letters-patents give me leave:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: My father's goods are all distrain'd and sold,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And these and all are all amiss employ'd.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: What would you have me do? I am a subject,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me;

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: And therefore, personally I lay my claim

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To my inheritance of free descent.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The noble duke hath been too much abused.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: It stands your grace upon to do him right.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Base men by his endowments are made great.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: My lords of England, let me tell you this:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I have had feeling of my cousin's wrongs

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And laboured all I could to do him right;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But in this kind to come, in braving arms,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be his own carver and cut out his way,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To find out right with wrong, it may not be;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And you that do abet him in this kind

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Cherish rebellion and are rebels all.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The noble duke hath sworn his coming is

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But for his own; and for the right of that

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And let him ne'er see joy that breaks that oath!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Well, well, I see the issue of these arms:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I cannot mend it, I must needs confess,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Because my power is weak and all ill left:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But if I could, by Him that gave me life,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I would attach you all and make you stoop

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Unto the sovereign mercy of the king;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But since I cannot, be it known to you

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I do remain as neuter. So, fare you well;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Unless you please to enter in the castle

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And there repose you for this night.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: An offer, uncle, that we will accept:

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: But we must win your grace to go with us

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: To Bristol castle, which they say is held

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: By Bushy, Bagot and their complices,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: The caterpillars of the commonwealth,

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Which I have sworn to weed and pluck away.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: It may be I will go with you: but yet I'll pause;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For I am loath to break our country's laws.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Nor friends nor foes, to me welcome you are:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Things past redress are now with me past care.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt
